node.title: They (Kind of) Have His Father to Thank for a First Date
node.description: Denrick Kimathi Cooper Jr. borrowed some cash from his dad to take Elizabeth Comer on what she called “the best first date I ever had.”
node.content: ["For his first date with Elizabeth Comer, Dr. Denrick Kimathi Cooper Jr. had to ask his dad for a favor.", "\u201cUnfortunately, I was broke, and had to ask my father for $20 for my first date with Liz,\u201d he said.", "Dr. Cooper, 34, who was born in New York City and goes by his African middle name Kimathi, first connected with Ms. Comer when they matched on the dating app Tinder on June 24, 2014. A graduate of Princeton, he had recently completed medical school at Case Western Reserve University in Cleveland and returned to the city to start a residency in emergency medicine at Mount Sinai Morningside and Mount Sinai West hospitals in Manhattan.", "Ms. Comer, 34, a North Carolina native, graduated from North Carolina State University and moved to Manhattan at about the same time to work at the New York office of Credit Suisse, a Swiss investment bank.", "Her roommates told her she had to download Tinder because \u201c\u2018like, everyone has it here.\u2019 Lucky for me, my first Tinder date was this charming New Yorker,\u201d she said.", "\u201cI remember thinking she was really good looking,\u201d Dr. Cooper said. \u201cWe texted back and forth a few days before I finally asked her out for drinks.\u201d", "The day of their first date, at Art Bar in Manhattan, Ms. Comer stopped a block away from the location to switch her work flats for a cute pair of wedges. When she entered, she saw Dr. Cooper sitting at the end of the bar. \u201cHe was even more handsome than his pictures,\u201d she said.", "Dr. Cooper was taken aback not only by Ms. Comer\u2019s good looks, but also by her southern accent. \u201cIt made her all the more charming,\u201d he said. \u201cWe had great conversations and chemistry right off the bat. We talked about everything: music, family, sports, dreams, goals. A lot for a first date.\u201d", "With an eye on the dwindling cash in his wallet, he and Ms. Comer spent the evening bar hopping until Dr. Cooper had enough courage, \u201cmaybe liquid courage,\u201d he said, to kiss her good night.", "\u201cIt was the best first date I ever had,\u201d Ms. Comer said. \u201cWe talked about way more than most couples discuss on a first date, but for some reason it worked. I was on cloud nine when I left, and we texted pretty regularly over the next week.\u201d", "[Click here to binge read this week\u2019s featured couples.]", "Dr. Cooper said, \u201cWe planned our next date a few days after and have been together ever since.Ms. Comer described their ensuing relationship as \u201cslow and steady wins the race.\u201d", "\u201cWe saw each other when we could,\u201d she said. \u201cBecause of his long hours at the hospital, \u2018nap dates\u2019 were acceptable.\u201d", "After his residency, Dr. Cooper pursued a passion for international health care by enrolling in Columbia University\u2019s Global Emergency Medical Fellowship, which awarded him a master\u2019s degree in public health upon completion.", "In 2019, the couple moved to New Orleans when Dr. Cooper was offered an attending emergency physician position at a hospital there. He is now a director of international emergency medicine at the Ochsner Medical Center in New Orleans.", "Ms. Comer works as a senior development officer in the New Orleans office of the Posse Foundation, a nonprofit organization that offers merit-based college scholarships to high school students.", "The couple were wed Oct. 24 in an outdoor ceremony at the Ridge, an events space in Marshall, N.C., with views of the Blue Ridge Mountains. The Rev. David Comer, the bride\u2019s uncle, officiated and the Rev. Abija Cooper, the groom\u2019s cousin, participated in the ceremony. All 170 guests were strongly encouraged to be fully vaccinated 14 days before the event, and unvaccinated guests wore masks.", "\u201cI have never felt so much love and joy in one day,\u201d Ms. Comer said.", "\u201cThe wedding did not play out the same way I pictured it in my head,\u201d Dr. Cooper added. \u201cNot in a bad way, but because there is no way to even imagine the amount of love, joy and happiness that was surrounding us.\u201d"]
